I've only played through the main story quest, but I've enjoyed my time in Toram. Here are my thoughts as a casual/solo player:

[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
    [*]The game has nostalgic retro graphics and a great soundtrack, and the character designs are cute.
    [*]The story is surprisingly good for an MMO.
    [*]Combat is fun, and there is no class system so you can use skills from any skill tree.
    [*]The game still receives regular updates and main story expansions.
    [*]You can recruit your guild members' characters as NPCs, which makes it much easier to play the game solo.
    [*]You can farm money fairly easily and buy player-made gear from the auction, which allows you to skip a lot of grinding.
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
    [*]Combat seems unbalanced. Nearly every attack will kill you in one hit, so gear that increases your health or defense seems useless.

    [*]Refunding your skill points costs premium currency, so you cannot experiment with your build. Instead, if you want to try a different playstyle you need to create and level a new character. The game's systems are a bit convoluted, so you will likely waste skill points if you don't follow a guide.

    [*]You need to create multiple characters for specific purposes since stat points are limited and also cannot be refunded for free. For example, you need a mage character with high luck to farm drops optimally, and you need another character with high vitality to craft gear and consumables with maximum success rate.

    [*]The game was originally designed for mobile devices and is not at all optimized for PC. Even with a good PC, you will find yourself staring at a lengthy loading screen every time you start the game or enter a new area for the first time. The UI is also designed with mobile in mind, so it's often unresponsive and unintuitive.

    [*]You will often find bots spamming links in the chat in the main city, and large groups of bots farming enemies in certain areas.

    [*]A lot of cosmetic items are locked behind a gacha system.
[/list]

Toram Online is a fun MMO to play casually, but not one I can see myself spending thousands of hours in. I'd rate it 6/10.

I've only played through the main story quest, but I've enjoyed my time in Toram. Here are my thoughts as a casual/solo player:

[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
    [*]The game has nostalgic retro graphics and a great soundtrack, and the character designs are cute.
    [*]The story is surprisingly good for an MMO.
    [*]Combat is fun, and there is no class system so you can use skills from any skill tree.
    [*]The game still receives regular updates and main story expansions.
    [*]You can recruit your guild members' characters as NPCs, which makes it much easier to play the game solo.
    [*]You can farm money fairly easily and buy player-made gear from the auction, which allows you to skip a lot of grinding.
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
    [*]Combat seems unbalanced. Nearly every attack will kill you in one hit, so gear that increases your health or defense seems useless.

    [*]Refunding your skill points costs premium currency, so you cannot experiment with your build. Instead, if you want to try a different playstyle you need to create and level a new character. The game's systems are a bit convoluted, so you will likely waste skill points if you don't follow a guide.

    [*]You need to create multiple characters for specific purposes since stat points are limited and also cannot be refunded for free. For example, you need a mage character with high luck to farm drops optimally, and you need another character with high vitality to craft gear and consumables with maximum success rate.

    [*]The game was originally designed for mobile devices and is not at all optimized for PC. Even with a good PC, you will find yourself staring at a lengthy loading screen every time you start the game or enter a new area for the first time. The UI is also designed with mobile in mind, so it's often unresponsive and unintuitive.

    [*]You will often find bots spamming links in the chat in the main city, and large groups of bots farming enemies in certain areas.

    [*]A lot of cosmetic items are locked behind a gacha system.
[/list]

Toram Online is a fun MMO to play casually, but not one I can see myself spending thousands of hours in. I'd rate it 6/10.

I write this review coming from someone who's played since the beta.  I love this game with all my heart and I keep coming back to it time and time again, even after long breaks.  I give this a negative review mostly due to the developers not really paying attention to the PC port's broken issue (to this day) security system.

Sure, RPG devs are not cyber security devs and I understand that they're focusing on growth, but the fact PC players can't really experience this without either breaking TOS, or having to disable their own built in firewall is a bit much.  For your own sake, either call attention to this more with me or just, download the mobile port instead.  It maybe a headache with the way text chat is in the game, but it's better than having to remove vital systems for cyber security, or being outright IP banned for VPN usage.

That being said, RPG is great.  Decent story, actual good mechanics that have a decent amount of variety due to its unique skill tree system.  You don't have to max it out or basically get restricted to whatever skill only fits your equipment.  I would say the only restrictions in this game are really only being able to invest into two stats at once at minimum, and three stats on different scales if you really know what you're doing.  For beginners reading this: 

Strength: You hit harder physically, and deal more critical damage as the hidden bonus stat.  It's great for becoming a glass cannon for halberd, increasing your crit fantasies as a katana, hitting harder with your two handed weapon (be chicken leg or warhammer, or badass sword) and hybrid damage builds (hybrid meaning you can deal both physical and magic damage).  This scales well with 2 Handed Swords and Halberds, scales moderately with 1 Handed Swords, then minorly with Katanas, Knuckles, and Bows.

Intelligence: Magic good, you get 1 free mana point per 100 int investment, and it's a really reliable stat both for and against magic due to magic defense being a part of this stat.  Sure, you need to invest into the last tier of battle skills tree to get crit chance for magic, but it always hits unless if it's a directional magic that is fixed to attack one area, like a magic skill called finale.  A lot of skills also utilize this stat so it's not insane to put this on some outlandish builds, but still keep it within reason, don't bottleneck your skill points for some insane wizard build. This scales well with Staffs and Magic Devices, and some other weapons with int scaling stats that are kind of specific models of weapons.

Vitality: It makes your physical armor and HP go up.  Really straight forward but it also helps on the tank builds tremendously.  Knight, Shield, and Darkness skill trees utilize vitality for their own ends, Knight uses it for both offensive and defensive bonuses as well as drawing enemy attention (like a good tank).  Darkness utilizes it on its health consumption power scaling, more HP, more raw damage.  And Shields, it's mostly to boost your resistances, but shields are mostly independent of all scaling besides refinement on said shield.  This only scales with certain armor equipment, and a very select few weapons in terms of damage, this is more about enduring the worst of the worst (unfortunately, not against the rare Fatal Damage).

Dexterity: One of the best stats due to the amount of benefits from investment: accuracy, casting speed, small magic, and physical damage increase.  It's used in a stupid amount of damage builds and even used in reliable tank builds due to accuracy being that main thing tanks lack without this.  It scales good with Katanas, Bows, Bowguns, Staves, Magic Devices, scales moderately with 1 Handed Swords, Knuckles, and scales poorly with 2 handed swords.

Agility: This is purely if you're wanting to either cosplay any Jojo character really, or if you love being an evasive person who deals not damage per hit, but damage per second.  This stat helps with evasion regeneration + capacity, and attack speed.  This scales good with Halberds, Knuckles, and scales poorly with Magic Devices.

And for the "hidden" stats, here's the last summary:

Tech; you make equipment good and get 1 free mana point per 100 invested into, basically a smith, alchemist, and refiner's best friend in terms of making god tier equipment, but man it makes said character you invest it into weaker due to low damage scaling. 

Crt: very straight forward, just critical chance & damage boost, great on every character who deals in crits (which is almost everyone).

Res: Resist all status ailments like a stoic chad, and really, most status effects are laughable if you're a tank built for every punishment with this stat on.

Luck: your drop rates increase.  And despite what some folks try to gaslight you into: no, it does not effect the party, only yourself.  Damn great for farming materials.

Last part to succeed, research bosses you can farm for good equipment or money making, power level with random folks due to it being harder alone (always ask for parties and don't be afraid to be friendly, everyone's usually nice when it comes to farming most things), and always avoid the text roleplay folks in towns, they're the biggest repulsion to the game, and it happens a lot in all RPGs when it comes to free to play MMORPGs.  Grinds feel nice, the combat loop isn't too similar thankfully, just enough to mix things up to not feel like you're draining your brain when it comes to boss farming due to their AI kind of being chaotic at times, or certain bosses having mechanics that piss them off if you use them, and it can result in a party wipe if you're not careful.

Most Toram players would say that it's one of the better or even the best Asobimo game, but that still doesn't mean it's a good game. The community is full of people who will never quit because of the time and money they have spent in this game, or can't look past their nostalgia. The management is terrible, frequent server crashes, a toxic community and microtransactions everywhere.

Speaking of microtransactions... that's the only area where Asobimo does not disappoint. There's cosmetics for sale, and that would be fine except they're strictly gacha-only. The drop rates are abysmal and cosmetics aren't even guaranteed. There's also an extra enchantment system on your cosmetic slot, where you can add extra stats to your character- in another gacha, of course. Some powerful items that are insanely rare to acquire through regular gameplay are conveniently available in the gacha too. And they're tradable, which is how you can turn your cold hard cash into worthless spina [the in-game currency] if you wish. You can even buy access to what is arguably the best source of XP, Adventurer Diaries, which are basically one-time use items to reset your main campaign and allow you to gain XP from it all over again. 

Next up is combat. It's fun at first, something unique and interesting, with a plethora of status effects and afflictions that are either not explained at all or poorly translated within a paragraph with no visual reference. Skill descriptions are so vague and misleading that they aren't even mysterious, just outright terrible. But if you still stick through and decide to slog through the early game, no one will want to party up with you because you're still new, and your damage is miniscule. If you still enjoy the combat and decide to build up your own unique class or playstyle, it won't matter in the endgame as most people follow two paths. You're either a glass cannon dps with zero survivability or you're the tank. Supports and tanky dps exist, but they're usually avoided or even kicked out of parties because most people don't play this game for the combat anyways. Parties want more drops, and that means sticking to the meta, or being kicked. Fast kill parties are mind-numbing and a disappointment to the wider combat system in general. You can directly blame how certain skills are designed to contribute to this.

The economy is rotting away too, since there's a huge amount of bots, which is obvious as it's the first thing you'll see in the chat as a new player. The main city always has bots advertising spina for sale or even links to scam websites.

TL;DR I wouldn't recommend this to anyone I care about. If your friend is asking you to play this game, find new friends immediately.
